Comment: I've always like the English Opening. White will aim to control the light squares in the center of the board.
Black responds symmetrically. The game could easily transpose into a variation of the Sicilian at this point.
Black plays for a flank attack, keeping his center Pawns in reserve for the moment. Very Hypermodern-like.
Black plays for a flank attack, keeping his center Pawns in reserve for the moment. Very Hypermodern-like.
I, too, hold back my center Pawns. Black follows up with the completion of the fianchetto.
I, too, hold back my center Pawns. Black follows up with the completion of the fianchetto.
If Black were to develop his King Knight, the position would be entirely symmetrical. I'm not afraid of playing for a draw and trying to squeeze a win in the endgame.
If Black were to develop his King Knight, the position would be entirely symmetrical. I'm not afraid of playing for a draw and trying to squeeze a win in the endgame.
If Black were to develop his King Knight, the position would be entirely symmetrical. I'm not afraid of playing for a draw and trying to squeeze a win in the endgame.
The first center thrust...
...and I parry. Black still has the option of going for symmetry.
Now the game really begins, as symmetry is broken.
Black wants to seize a central advantage...
Black wants to seize a central advantage...
...which I prevent.
Black offers to trade Knights. This would plant his Pawn at d4, but I feel I get sufficient compensation by being able to place my Queen Knight at d5 after the exchange.
This capture leaves me with a Queen-side advantage in the potential endgame. I would have used the e-pawn instead.
This capture leaves me with a Queen-side advantage in the potential endgame. I would have used the e-pawn instead.
Black completes his development. The Knight on e7 is vulnerable to the pin...
Black completes his development. The Knight on e7 is vulnerable to the pin...
The pin, they say, is mightier than the sword. I'm not sure how Black can escape without material loss. 10...Nxd5 was probably a better alternative, to be followed by 11...O-O.
The best Black can do now is end up down the Exchange.
The logical follow-up. I was expecting 12...Rxe7 13 Bxe7 Qxe7, which would have left me with an exchange up but still some work to do to secure the win.
Catastrophic. Now the killer discovery seals things quickly.
Black resigns, as he loses his Queen if he plays on.
